newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Senior China official sees no change on Deng death.
newsitem.headline: Senior China official sees no change on Deng death.

text.p: A senior Chinese official in charge of exchanges across the Taiwan Strait said on Thursday that the death of paramount leader Deng Xiaoping would not change China's relations with Taiwan.

"I believe China will not change because of Deng's death and there will not be any change in cross-strait relations either," Wang Xiaomin, deputy director of the exchange bureau of China's Taiwan Affairs Office, said during a cultural visit to Taipei.

"His (Deng's) death is our biggest loss, but I believe he will live in my heart forever," Wang said on Taiwan's state-run television. Wang is a daughter-in-law of China's retired parliament chief and Communist Party politburo member Wan Li.
Deng died in Beijing late on Wednesday at 92.

Deng's reforms and open-door policy in China had formed a strong consensus on the mainland and the current reform pace would not change regardless of who became Deng's successor, the Taiwanese television quoted Wang as saying.
Wang started an eight-day visit to Taiwan on Thursday with 29 other Chinese delegates to promote cultural exchanges between the two sides, rivals since a civil war ended in 1949.

The group includes delegation leader Bayinqolu, a vice president of the All-China Youth Federation and a secretary of the Communist Youth League of China, and Cheng Jinzhong, a director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council.
Only through exchanges between Taiwan and China would they promote understanding between the two sides, Wang said.
Nineteen months ago, China clamped a freeze on what had been slowly warming unofficial ties with Taiwan, which Beijing has seen as a renegade province since 1949.
Both governments in Taipei and Beijing say they want reunification, but under very different terms.

The strained relations were caused by a controversial visit to the United States by Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui in June 1995, a trip interpreted by Beijing as an attempt to promote independence of the island.
Wang's group is scheduled to visit cultural, educational and scientific establishments in Taiwan during their stay, Taiwanese organisers have said.
